text:

at Squarespace.com/HAI.
As we all know, Australians are terrible people.

They’re hell-bent on exclusionary policies
that keep these cute little guys away from

the south-east all because, well I actually
don’t know why. I should look it up.

Huh. Ok so as it turns out dingos suck and
Australians are alright. In summary, these

beasts eat sheep and make them deceased so
increased police and this fence kept them

from the south-east and help decrease the
feast, capisce? Good, now to unsummarize.

Dingos are like dogs, but worse. Instead of
eating Purina they’ll eat anything—kangaroo,

rats, cows, wallaby, sheep, fish, etc—and
that’s a problem because farmers like their

sheep and cows alive. Dingo attacks on humans,
while rare, have also happened. In the most

notable case, a two month old baby girl was
taken from her tent by Dingoes and killed

while she and her parents were camping at
Ayers Rock. The mother of the girl was tried

and convicted for murder and spent more than
three years in prison before it was proven

that dingoes killed the girl. She was released
and given $1.5 million in compensation which

sounds nice, except her legal expenses amounted
to over $4 million, so she wasn’t happy.

But that case really had nothing to do with
the building of the dingo fence because this

fence was built in the 1800’s. What you
have to remember about Australia is that almost

everyone lives here. In fact, only 18% of
the population lives in the Northern Territory,

West Australia, or Southern Australia even
though these regions account for 63% of the

area of the country. Now, a big reason so
much of the population lives in the south-east

is because it’s the most fertile area and
since sheep eat wheat in the south-east…

I’m just kidding we’re not doing this
again. Because this area is more fertile this

region is where most farms are and as we learned
earlier dingoes plus animals equals just dingoes

because they eat everything, and just as an
only somewhat related side-note, there’s

a cattle farm in Australia that’s larger
than the country of Belize.

Moving on, in order to separate the fertile,
populated area of Australia from the dry,

deadly animal region of Australia the government
built a 3,488 mile long fence. Now, this

fence didn’t even start as an anti-dingo
fence, it was originally for rabbits. In 1859,

24 rabbits were released into the wild in
Australia by Thomas Austin—a guy whose only

legacy is doing exactly this. From those 24
the population of these crop-eating demons

grew to 600 million and so the first wave
of fence building was all centered around

creating rabbit free areas where settlers
could grow food. As you may know, Australia

has had a long and respected history of fighting
animals which came to a climax when they literally

had a war, like with guns and soldiers and
all that, they literally had a war with emus.

With the rabbits, although, as it turned out
the fence pretty much sucked at controlling

them—something about them being able to
jump or something—but as dingoes grew in

population and got more destructive the government
decided they needed to protect the farmland

and spent millions and millions of dollars
to make the fence bigger.

Now to address the elephant in the room. I
know all of you are waiting for a Donald Trump

wall joke, and you’re not getting it.
Now, the fence was built in sections at different

times but by the mid-1900s it was complete,
and this fence is immense. It stretches 3,488

miles long—that’s longer than two football
fields—and six feet high, and it’s continuous.

It spans from South Australia all the way
to about 100 miles west of Brisbane, and it

does a decently good job of keeping the dingoes
out. If you overlay the density of dingoes

you can see that they’re significantly less
common in the south-east and so the fence

sort-of works. As crazy of a concept the fence
is, it is economically sound. The fence costs

about $10 million yearly to maintain while
increased dingo attacks on livestock in the

south-east would cost many times more than
that. As crazy as it is, it actually is a

good deal… but what’s also a good deal
is Squarespace.

or a website, when making a decision you have
